data.title: Alone (2020) Filming Locations
data.meta_description: "Alone," directed by, tells the compelling story of Jessica, a recently divorced woman whose solo road trip turns into a nightmare when she becomes the target
data.text:
“Alone,” directed by, tells the compelling story of Jessica, a recently divorced woman whose solo road trip turns into a nightmare when she becomes the target of a cunning attacker. When Jessica encounters a mysterious man on a remote highway, she quickly realizes that his intentions are far from friendly. What follows is a heart-pounding cat and mouse game in which Jessica fights for her life against her relentless pursuer. The scary parts of the movie make people want to find out more, especially about where it was filmed.

Setting the Stage for Isolation and Vulnerability

The film’s setting is crucial in amplifying Jessica’s feelings of isolation and vulnerability. Her predicament becomes more palpable when set against the backdrop of vast forests and desolate highways. The expansive and unpredictable landscapes heighten the suspense, so viewers may wonder where the filming took place.

Alone Filming Locations

“Alone” was shot at several locations in Oregon, including Portland, Estacada, and Mount Hood National Forest. Principal photography began in April 2018 and concluded on May 6, 2018. Despite the difficulties of filming, the cast and crew relished the excitement of the action-packed scenes, including those that required actors to be covered in mud.

Exploring Specific Filming Sites

Portland, Oregon

Portland served as a cinematic backdrop for several scenes in the film, including Jessica’s road trip initiation across a picturesque suspension bridge. The iconic St. Johns Bridge, which spans the Willamette River, contributed to the film’s atmospheric charm.

Estacada, Oregon

Estacada, located southeast of Portland, was an important location in the film “Alone,” with its rugged terrain and stunning vistas. It served as the backdrop for pivotal scenes in the story, heightening Jessica’s sense of isolation and tension. The remote gas station encounter scene was shot at a specific location on South East Main Street.

Mount Hood National Forest, Oregon

The film’s adrenaline-fueled scenes were set in the breathtaking Mount Hood National Forest in Oregon, known for its untamed wilderness. Jessica faced physical and psychological challenges as she fought for survival in the wilderness, worsened by the dense foliage and rugged terrain.

“Alone” captivates audiences with its gripping narrative and immersive filming locations. From the eerie isolation of Estacada to the untamed beauty of Mount Hood National Forest, the settings enhance the tension and suspense of Jessica’s harrowing journey. As viewers are drawn into the wilderness alongside Jessica, they experience the full intensity of her fight for survival against a cunning predator.

Official Trailer

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) – Alone (2020)

Q: Where Was “Alone” (2020) Filmed?

A: “Alone” (2020) was primarily filmed across various locations in Portland, Estacada, and Mount Hood National Forest in Oregon. These settings provided the backdrop for the gripping tale of Jessica’s harrowing journey.

Q: Why Were These Locations Chosen for Filming?

A: The filming locations for “Alone” (2020) were chosen to enhance Jessica’s sense of isolation and vulnerability. The vast forests, desolate highways, and remote towns added to the film’s atmospheric charm.

Q: When Was “Alone” (2020) Filmed?

A: Principal photography for “Alone” (2020) began in April 2018 and wrapped up by May 6, 2018. Despite facing challenges such as intense heatwaves, the cast and crew successfully completed filming within this timeframe.

Q: What Are Some Specific Filming Sites Featured in “Alone” (2020)?

A: Specific filming locations in “Alone” (2020) include Portland’s St. Johns Bridge, Estacada’s remote gas station on South East Main Street, and Mount Hood National Forest’s breathtaking landscapes. These locations lent depth and authenticity to the film’s story.
